a little bit of a definition of what game design is here If you already know I'm sorry Um the way I like to define it
for people who are a little unfamiliar because most people think I'm a coder which a little but not really Uh what I
really am is um we are architects of a game systems and the user experience
within those systems So we often advocate for our players and for our users We are the gatekeeper of their
journey and progression through those systems Um our work is a lot about the rules and the playground that we create
for our users and we care a lot about their enjoyment and infusing our work
with meaning and engagement um to get people through the content in an
enjoyable manner Um and I actually believe that every experience that is made for humans in any kind of way from
you know a video game to a microwave can benefit from some of this approach and from like thinking about it the way that
game designers do I also want to point out a few points
that I see whenever people for the first time engage with uh with games as an
inspiration for other software because the easiest and to me sometimes
frustrating route is for them to think about uh it as a simulation So it's an
easy pitch to go "Oh you have this training that you do with your whatever how many people and you have to like
rent a facility and rent a trainer and like rent whatever kind of stuff to make
it happen Just make it into a game and then people don't have to travel somewhere and they understand the cost
cutting benefit of replicating real world scenarios." But I always get frustrated with that
because it often does not offer much more beyond that replica and it misses out on the real power of video games and
is lacking the imagination that I would like for people to recognize as important and useful Uh and quite often
it's actually more expensive to make than having a better or more imaginative approach to it Uh whereas games on the
other hand if you think about them if you're not afraid of that term if you're not afraid of it being like a playful experience uh then you can recognize
that they are about mastery um and translating concepts into digestible
engaging experiences So we very often when we make games have a deliberate progression curve through that content
and we are very intentional about teaching people in like a a sensible manner that sticks you know um we have
an inherent concept um and value of promoting gradual mastery within the
worlds that we make and you know as I said before I believe that play and meaning are the most natural ways for
any human to learn um in general Okay So with all that being said
I do want to get into the practical part of this Uh I want to give you a a model that you can use to think about your own
software your own applications your own whatever you're making that will help And there's a you know as many methods
for that as there are game designers And I I'm picking out one that wasn't done by me but that I found to be the most
valuable for people to start thinking about it that way Um it's made by Daniel Cook uh he wrote an article called the
chemistry chemistry of game design Look it up It's amazing Um and it's it's
basically like a skill tree approach that thinks about every single action that the player or the user needs to
take to learn uh how to play your game or how to use your application from button clicks to pretty
much anything And I'll give an example on how it works and then we'll look at how we made that in uh in
Armus Okay So I want you to think of an action that your player can take a
learning action if you want uh and break it up into these few things So there's a user action then there's an in-game or
under the hood process of sorts then there's feedback back to the player and then there's an updated mental model And
the the lower part is really the important part here Uh to give you an example like a concrete example it would
look something like this for something like Super Mario which I hope everyone knows I feel like we've it's been old
enough that everyone knows what Super Mario is So I'm hoping you understand Uh so this is an example of what the first
action would be One of the most important things you need to learn is jumping So the user action here is
pressing the jump button Then there's an in-game process underneath underneath the hood which is jumping and colliding
if uh if applicable And then the feedback is the animation plays for the player to observe and the updated mental
model The important part is I can jump Now we do want to start chaining
these things together Um as an example it would look like something like this
After I've learned jumping I can learn the next best thing which is I want to reach a platform So the action again is
jumping near a platform The under the hood process is jumping and colliding
And then the animation playing is the feedback that the player is getting And the updated mental model again it's
building on top of the other one is I can get higher by jumping onto platforms
Now I do want to point out that uh the previous node here the jumping node has
uh a markup here that we call model burnout Um you can use this in all kinds
of different ways So there's no like fixed rules for it Uh I use it usually
to decide when I feel like uh a skill has been performed enough times so I can
introduce more elements So that can be all kinds of things you know it can be you need to do this 50 times or three
times or whatever once sometimes uh that matters and sometimes you can use it for testing too So there's multiple
applications for that but it's important for you to understand how these things have to relate to each other and when
